results:
Based on my search results, I found confirmation that Leopold Staff did indeed translate Goethe's "The Sorrows of Young Werther" into Polish, and that editions exist with Daniel Chodowiecki's illustrations. Here's what I discovered:

## Leopold Staff's Polish Translation with Chodowiecki Illustrations

There is a Polish edition titled "Cierpienia młodego Wertera" translated by Leopold Staff with reproductions of Daniel Chodowiecki's copper engravings (miedzioryty in Polish).

### About Leopold Staff

Leopold Staff was an influential poet and translator associated with the Young Poland movement at the end of the 19th century. He was a Polish poet and artist of European modernism who was twice granted honorary doctorate degrees by universities in Warsaw and Kraków, and was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature by Polish PEN Club.

### About Daniel Chodowiecki's Illustrations

Daniel Niklaus Chodowiecki (1726-1801) was a Polish painter and printmaker with partial Huguenot ancestry, most famous as an etcher who spent most of his later life in Berlin and became director of the Berlin Academy of Art.

His book illustrations embrace almost all the great classics, and he created multiple illustrations for "The Sorrows of Young Werther," including engravings of "Werther's room" and scenes of "Charlotte and Werther".

### The Edition

A specific edition was published by "Książka i Wiedza" in Warsaw in 1986 as the 7th edition, consisting of 191 pages in 17cm format.

This combination represents an important intersection of German literature, Polish translation, and 18th-century illustration art, bringing together Goethe's seminal work of the Sturm und Drang period with Staff's acclaimed translation skills and Chodowiecki's masterful engravings.
